body:
In most cases the CPU is much slower than a GPU, so the GPU is preferred.
In Linux you set the environment variable `CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES`.

Example (Sets training on CPU):
```
CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES="" <your training command>
```

Example (Sets training on GPU X, where X is the GPU ID, starting at 0):
```
CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES="X" <your training command>
```

For Windows you need to do some research, how env variables work.

A quick google search resulted in the following command for Windows systems:
```
set CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES="" & <your training command>
```

Thank you for your help @Flova . I tried using the command (in windows 10 prompt set CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES="0" OR set CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES="1" OR set CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES="2" OR set CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES="3">) but it didn't work. None of the versions of deepfacelab work on my pc (cuda, OpenCL, nvidia).
Do you have any other tips to suggest to me? 
Is it possible to use my video card by bypassing the error message regarding the low memory of the video card?

No problem.
Did you run the environment variable command and the training command both in the same line of the command prompt? If not, do so.
Use the CUDA Version of the software. By hiding the CUDA devices, the training should move to the CPU.
In your case, you want all CUDA devices to be hidden, so you should set `CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES=""` instead of `CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES="0"` or some other GPU ID.
It is probably not so useful/realistic to use the GPU if the memory requirements are over its capabilities. Even if it would be possible, accessing the system ram from the GPU would be a huge bottleneck.

Hi, I started the Command Prompt with admin privilege and I wrote `set cuda_device_""` OR `set cuda_device_"" 6) train H64.bat` , in the c: \ DeepFaceLab_OpenCL_01-11-2020 folder,in the c: \ DeepFaceLab_1.0_CUDA_build_01-11-2020 folder, and in C:\ DeepFaceLab_NVIDIA_build_02_03_2020 folder, but nothing happens after writing these commands. Maybe I should edit the plaidml.jeras.backend file, but I don't understand where in the code. When I try to start "6) train H64.bat" in safe mode it works correctly with the cpu.

I am not so familiar with the windows. But in your case it sounds like you want to run:
`set CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES="" & 6) train H64.bat` in the CUDA version. The `&` and the case sensitivity are important!

Thanks again for your help @Flova . It finally works!
If I open the Command Prompt with admin privilege and I write `set CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES="" & 6) train H64.bat` , in the c:\DeepFaceLab_OpenCL_01-11-2020 folder,in the c:\DeepFaceLab_1.0_CUDA_build_01-11-2020 folder, and in C:\DeepFaceLab_NVIDIA_build_02_03_2020 folder, I'm getting the following error: 

> "6)" is not recognized as an internal or external command, operable program or batch file.

To fix it I had to rename the file "6) train H64.bat" to "trainH64.bat". I add that only the OpenCL version works with my CPU. Cuda and Nvidia don't work.

DeepFaceLab OpenCL now works perfectly with the CPU.
DeepFaceLab NVIDIA and DeepFaceLab CUDA still don't work and I don't understand why.
I report the errors I get when I try to use NVIDIA and CUDA.
